dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you're telling me, like, economists are basically primitive Tasmanians now? Is that what this article is, uh, trying to say?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you're telling me, like, economists are basically primitive Tasmanians now? Is that what this article is, uh, trying to say?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's, um, it's drawing a parallel, right? Between geographic isolation leading to a loss of cultural knowledge, and, uh, intellectual isolation doing the same.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's, um, it's drawing a parallel, right? Between geographic isolation leading to a loss of cultural knowledge, and, uh, intellectual isolation doing the same.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To see how isolation can disrupt and even reverse this process, consider Tasmania, which some 12,000 years ago was separated from mainland Australia... The same thing can happen to professional groups and academic disciplines. Mainstream economists and economic policymakers are a case in point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Loss of knowledge? Come on. They're economists, not, like, forgetting how to make fire. What does that even mean in, uh, a modern context?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Loss of knowledge? Come on. They're economists, not, like, forgetting how to make fire. What does that even mean in, uh, a modern context?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, but, uh, it means they've, like, lost sight of tools they once commonly used, fiscal policy, you know? Ignoring it since, um, the 2008 crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, but, uh, it means they've, like, lost sight of tools they once commonly used, fiscal policy, you know? Ignoring it since, um, the two thousand eight crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The resulting intellectual isolation has not only made tribe members unable to share, generate, and recombine ideas that do not conform to the orthodoxy, but also has led them to reject policy tools that were widely used in the past. The most significant example is fiscal policy, which has been repeatedly spurned as a response to stagnant or declining demand and falling private investment during economic downturns. This attitude has been starkly apparent since the 2008 global financial crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, they chose to ignore it? Or did it just, uh, not work? The article says they printed trillions, kept rates low. That sounds pretty active to me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, they chose to ignore it? Or did it just, uh, not work? The article says they printed trillions, kept rates low. That sounds pretty active to me.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since 2008, advanced-economy central banks have printed more than $20 trillion, and slashed interest rates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It was active, yes, but, uh, monetary policy, mostly. The article argues it was a narrow dogma, resisting new ideas, like on sustainable finance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It was active, yes, but, uh, monetary policy, mostly. The article argues it was a narrow dogma, resisting new ideas, like on sustainable finance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For four decades, this tribe has been wedded to a particular dogma, comprising a narrow set of principles and mechanisms... they focused almost exclusively on monetary policy, while dismissing fiscal policy out of hand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Sustainable finance? Are we really comparing, like, advanced economic theory to, uh, boomerang technology? That's a bit of a stretch, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sustainable finance? Are we really comparing, like, advanced economic theory to, uh, boomerang technology? That's a bit of a stretch, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Archaeological remains indicate that prior to this separation, Tasmanian and mainland populations possessed the same skills such as fire-making and technologies, including the boomerang, spear-thrower, and polished-stone and bone tools... The same thing can happen to professional groups and academic disciplines. Mainstream economists and economic policymakers are a case in point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The point is, though, that, um, the Tasmanians, they got cut off, and their toolkit shrunk. The economists, they've, like, cut themselves off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The point is, though, that, um, the Tasmanians, they got cut off, and their toolkit shrunk. The economists, they've, like, cut themselves off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In short, geographic isolation had caused them to lose significant cultural knowledge over generations... The same thing can happen to professional groups and academic disciplines. Mainstream economists and economic policymakers are a case in point. For four decades, this tribe has been wedded to a particular dogma... it has become increasingly inward-looking, resisting real interactions with others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But the Tasmanians, they faced a harsh climate. These economists, they're in air-conditioned offices. Totally different. The article tries to make it sound the same.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the Tasmanians, they faced a harsh climate. These economists, they're in air-conditioned offices. Totally different. The article tries to make it sound the same.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But the article explicitly says, um, the Tasmanians didn't choose isolation. Today, some societies are doing exactly that. And the consequences are, uh, regressive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the article explicitly says, um, the Tasmanians didn't choose isolation. Today, some societies are doing exactly that. And the consequences are, uh, regressive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Tasmanians did not choose their isolation. Yet, today, some societies and social groups are doing just that. And, as with the Tasmanians, this is having regressive effects, including the loss of both existing knowledge and some capacity to generate new knowledge and innovation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Regressive? So, what, the global economy is, like, going back to the Stone Age because economists won't, uh, spend more? Seems a bit dramatic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Regressive? So, what, the global economy is, like, going back to the Stone Age because economists won't, uh, spend more? Seems a bit dramatic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article does, um, warn of disastrous results, not just for the 'tribe' but for society. It mentions a loss of knowledge about fiscal multipliers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article does, um, warn of disastrous results, not just for the 'tribe' but for society. It mentions a loss of knowledge about fiscal multipliers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the tribe of economists and economic policymakers continues on its regressive path, the results, too, will be disastrous, not only for the tribe itself, but also for the societies in which it operates. This reflects a loss of knowledge about fiscal multipliers, which should and, historically, did guide government spending during downturns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Fiscal multipliers. Yeah, sure. Because printing $20 trillion and racking up $57 trillion in debt isn't a problem, right? They're just, like, being 'stubborn.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fiscal multipliers. Yeah, sure. Because printing twenty dollars trillion and racking up fifty seven dollars trillion in debt isn't a problem, right? They're just, like, being 'stubborn.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since 2008, advanced-economy central banks have printed more than $20 trillion, and slashed interest rates. Moreover, easy credit policies have allowed global debt to increase by around $57 trillion to more than three times global GDP.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The article does acknowledge, um, financial sector lobbying. But it says interest rates are so low now, they have few monetary tools left anyway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The article does acknowledge, um, financial sector lobbying. But it says interest rates are so low now, they have few monetary tools left anyway.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, this reliance on monetary policy and the specific tools that were employed largely reflected the financial sectors lobbying power... With interest rates still ultra-low or even negative in many countries, governments have few remaining monetary-policy tools with which to respond to a slowdown, let alone another recession.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what, we just, like, blindly spend then? Is that the solution? The Tasmanians got, uh, slaughtered in the end. Not exactly a hopeful analogy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what, we just, like, blindly spend then? Is that the solution? The Tasmanians got, uh, slaughtered in the end. Not exactly a hopeful analogy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Tasmanians suffered terribly for falling behind, with most being slaughtered by much more technologically advanced Europeans in the nineteenth century.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's not about blind spending, it's about, uh, using a full toolkit. And it's a warning, you know? The societies can still, um, override this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's not about blind spending, it's about, uh, using a full toolkit. And it's a warning, you know? The societies can still, um, override this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There is still time for those societies to save themselves, bringing their collective brains to bear to override this powerful tribes evident regression.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Override what? The 'blind belief in fiscal discipline'? So, we just throw money at problems because a bunch of insulated economists, uh, forgot how?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Override what? The 'blind belief in fiscal discipline'? So, we just throw money at problems because a bunch of insulated economists, uh, forgot how?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The blind belief in fiscal discipline and consolidation, reinforced over decades of isolation, now threatens the very stability of economies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not forgot how, but, um, refused to apply it. The intellectual isolation is the key point. Itâ€™s, like, a self-imposed limitation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not forgot how, but, um, refused to apply it. The intellectual isolation is the key point. It's, like, a self-imposed limitation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The crisis should have been a powerful reality check, yet it failed to shake mainstream economists and policymakers out of their self-imposed intellectual isolation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A self-imposed limitation that conveniently lets them, uh, blame everyone else when things go south, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A self-imposed limitation that conveniently lets them, uh, blame everyone else when things go south, I guess.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article does suggest that, uh, societies need to bring their collective brains to bear. So, it's, like, a call to action.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article does suggest that, uh, societies need to bring their collective brains to bear. So, it's, like, a call to action.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There is still time for those societies to save themselves, bringing their collective brains to bear to override this powerful tribes evident regression. Whether they will, however, remains to be seen.
